contentrichtext.text: <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Dumisani Khumalo.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Ambassador Dumisani Kumalo]] --> '''Dumisani Shadrack Kumalo''' (born 16 September 1947) is a [[South Africa]]n diplomat, previously serving as the [[Permanent Representative]] of South Africa to the [[United Nations]].<ref name=UN>[http://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/1999/19990421.bio3224.html "NEW PERMANENT REPRESENTATIVE OF SOUTH AFRICA PRESENTS CREDENTIALS"], UN Press Release, BIO/3224, 21 April 1999.</ref> In 1977 he was forced into exile for his anti-apartheid activities and sought asylum in the [[United States]], where he continued to work for South African liberation and democracy. As Project Director at the [[American Committee on Africa]] (ACOA) and its sister organization [[The Africa Fund]] from 1979 to 1997 he played a key role in the mobilization of U.S. sanctions against apartheid, helping to build the divestment movement which led to 28 states, 24 counties and more than 90 cities and 155 colleges and universities divesting from U.S. banks and companies which did business with apartheid South Africa. He visited almost every state in the union, testifying before state legislatures and city councils and speaking in communities and at countless colleges and universities. Before going into exile he worked as a political reporter for the ''Golden City Post'', ''[[Drum (South African magazine)|DRUM]]'', and the Johannesburg ''[[Sunday Times (South Africa)|Sunday Times]]''. After the end of apartheid he returned to South Africa and was appointed Director of the United States Desk in the Department of Foreign Affairs in 1997.<ref name=UN/> Kumalo was subsequently appointed as South Africa's Permanent Representative to the United Nations; he presented his credentials as Permanent Representative on 21 April 1999.<ref name=UN/> He spoke to the [[United Nations General Assembly]] on 13 April 2004, encouraging participation of the member nations of the [[United Nations]], on the matter of the [[Kimberley Process Certification Scheme]]. He is on the Advisory Committee of the African Activist Archive Project of the African Studies Center at [[Michigan State University]].[http://www.africanactivist.msu.edu/] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-dip}} {{s-bef|before= }} {{s-ttl|title=South African Ambassador to the United Nations|years= 21 April 1999 - 16 March 2009}} {{s-aft|after= [[Baso Sangqu]]}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | name = Kumalo, Dumisani | alternative names = | short description = Diplomat | date of birth = September 16, 1947 | place of birth = | date of death = | place of death = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kumalo, Dumisani}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South African diplomats]] [[Category:Anti-apartheid activists]] [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Permanent Representatives of South Africa to the United Nations]] [[Category:Presidents of the United Nations Security Council]] {{SouthAfrica-diplomat-stub}} {{AntiApartheid-activist-stub}}
